get application
You remove a starship requisition application from a leather briefcase.
read application
1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
5. You are part of a large combat force attacking an Outsider patrol. You easily
overwhelm them, but before you can take out the stragglers, a Magistrate-class
regional mothership appears. What do you and your allies do and why?
6. In the event of a large-scale invasion of human space by hostile forces, what
would be your priority and why?
7. In an emergency, you and your ship are placed at the disposal of a naval wing
commander. How do you feel you would handle this situation?
8. What are your starship combat experiences that do not include Accord-issues
missions, organised decoy beacons, or simulators?
9. What would you say is your greatest weakness as a combat pilot?
10. How long do you expect this ship to remain undamaged?
11. How would you predict this ship will be destroyed?
12. What do you plan to name this ship, should you acquire one?
13. You must choose a theme song that you will completely rock out to while
fighting. What song do you choose?
14. What is your favorite color?
read application
1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
5. You are part of a large combat force attacking an Outsider patrol. You easily
overwhelm them, but before you can take out the stragglers, a Magistrate-class
regional mothership appears. What do you and your allies do and why?
6. In the event of a large-scale invasion of human space by hostile forces, what
would be your priority and why?
7. In an emergency, you and your ship are placed at the disposal of a naval wing
commander. How do you feel you would handle this situation?
8. What are your starship combat experiences that do not include Accord-issues
missions, organised decoy beacons, or simulators?
9. What would you say is your greatest weakness as a combat pilot?
10. How long do you expect this ship to remain undamaged?
11. How would you predict this ship will be destroyed?
12. What do you plan to name this ship, should you acquire one?
13. You must choose a theme song that you will completely rock out to while
fighting. What song do you choose?
14. What is your favorite color?
use application
You scan the questions written on a starship requisition application and begin
filling them out.
(15 seconds roundtime.)
1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
I would attempt to destroy any chaining or interdicting ships before engaging
other ships in case I need to run. Having done so, I would attempt to cripple
the hostile force as much as possible. If the hostile force is left alone, it
could very well be strengthened by other forces in the area before finding its
way to civilian locations and causing destruction.
You entered: I would attempt to destroy any chaining or interdicting ships
before engaging other ships in case I need to run. Having done so, I would
attempt to cripple the hostile force as much as possible. If the hostile force
is left alone, it could very well be strengthened by other forces in the area
before finding its way to civilian locations and causing destruction.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
I would report my location, the number of ships and their classes over tactical
and ask for reinforcements. Then I would engage them as above, attempting to
make sure I have the ability to run and get repairs if necessary. With it being
a direct threat to a civilian location, I would continue to fight the ships
until they are all destroyed. If my ship gets destroyed, I would just grab
another ship. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human space from all
threats.
You entered: I would report my location, the number of ships and their classes
over tactical and ask for reinforcements. Then I would engage them as above,
attempting to make sure I have the ability to run and get repairs if necessary.
With it being a direct threat to a civilian location, I would continue to fight
the ships until they are all destroyed. If my ship gets destroyed, I would just
grab another ship. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human space from
all threats.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
I prefer to be short one gunner. Since AEU ships rely primarily on their lasers
and as such, use a lot of grid, I would much rather have someone able to
recharge the grid. IF the grid is completely drained, the ship's weapons become
much less effective. Against such ships as rapid assault ships or any assault
warpers, it is imperative that these ships be destroyed as quickly as possible.
When the ship does Get hit, the engineer's ability to be able to use a quick
patch readily can be the difference between losing a failsafe or not. Another
advantage of being short one gunner as opposed to being short an engineer is
that if the grid does get depleted in one weapon room, the gunner can move to
the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapon room is fully
charged again.
You entered: I prefer to be short one gunner. Since AEU ships rely primarily on
their lasers and as such, use a lot of grid, I would much rather have someone
able to recharge the grid. IF the grid is completely drained, the ship's weapons
become much less effective. Against such ships as rapid assault ships or any
assault warpers, it is imperative that these ships be destroyed as quickly as
possible. When the ship does Get hit, the engineer's ability to be able to use a
quick patch readily can be the difference between losing a failsafe or not.
Another advantage of being short one gunner as opposed to being short an
engineer is that if the grid does get depleted in one weapon room, the gunner
can move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapon
room is fully charged again.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
I engage any ships that are chaining me, destroy any interdictors and any ships
that are interdicting all the while getting as close to the edge as possible in
order to make a quick get away. Having taken note of the number of ships that
remain, I then land, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to determine how
many ships are in the hostile sector. I would wait long enough to find out how
many enemy ships responded as reinforcements. I would report all of this over
tactical and ask for assistance. If I am unable to escape from the sector, I
keep the ship moving, make repairs, land if possible and request assistance over
tactical.
You entered: I engage any ships that are chaining me, destroy any interdictors
and any ships that are interdicting all the while getting as close to the edge
as possible in order to make a quick get away. Having taken note of the number
of ships that remain, I then land, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to
determine how many ships are in the hostile sector. I would wait long enough to
find out how many enemy ships responded as reinforcements. I would report all of
this over tactical and ask for assistance. If I am unable to escape from the
sector, I keep the ship moving, make repairs, land if possible and request
assistance over tactical.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
5. You are part of a large combat force attacking an Outsider patrol. You easily
overwhelm them, but before you can take out the stragglers, a Magistrate-class
regional mothership appears. What do you and your allies do and why?
We engage and destroy the escorting ships and leave the sector as a mothership
cannot be destroyed by conventional weapons. The last mothership had to be
destroyed with the use of battle suits. Therefore, we leave and don't come back
unless we have cruisers that have the special shielding that can repel the PDB
and battle suits.

mothership cannot be destroyed by conventional weapons. The last mothership had
to be destroyed with the use of battle suits. Therefore, we leave and don't come
back unless we have cruisers that have the special shielding that can repel the
PDB and battle suits.

1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
Your ship 'Firestorm' has been automatically moved into a garage.
I engage any interdicting or chaining ships first then any other small ships
that I can destroy before leaving. My goal would be to cripple the hostile force
as much as possible. If they are left alone, they could be strengthened and find
their way to beacon sectors and attack civilian locations.

small ships that I can destroy before leaving. My goal would be to cripple the
hostile force as much as possible. If they are left alone, they could be

1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.

n
1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy any
interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many ships
as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be reinforced
and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My goal would
be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
You entered: I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy
any interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many
ships as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be
reinforced and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My
goal would be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and request
reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be placed on
stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the way, I would
engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy any
interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of the
enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance space
from all hostile threats.

3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily on lasers
that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is able to
recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is depleted, the
ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of being short a
gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can move to the
empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons room's grid is
recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer to apply quick
patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a failsafe or not.
Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can increase the damage
for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for being short a gunner.
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
_5QClpyH71!+eycIAUV~}2^#<AIq{dfCM|jibKn'
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
red
You lift a small plastic cover and press a red button.
A loud klaxon sounds and red lights flash overhead as the ship enters red alert.
You hear a low hum as the ship's weapons are powered up.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
shipc
There are no other ships in the sector.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to League Salvage Processing Nuclear Autonav Station in thirty seconds
unless aborted or another navigation order is entered."
The computer reports that the ares "Warship 011" has jumped out of the sector.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Firestorm.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.
tra 1 Orion clear.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Shule Elemmire, Phoenix Dissident transmits,
"Orion clear."
trace
Recent FTL Drive Traces:
AEU transport "Procyon" departed to AEU sector Providence Gate (Alpha-1)
approximately 3 minutes ago.
green
You lift a small plastic cover and press a green button.
You hear a single beep and glance up to see green lights flick on overhead as
the ship enters normal status.
A low hum you had barely noticed until now slowly fades away as weapons are
powered down.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Dakhal Araegin transmits, "Took it out, or did
it jump out?"
tra 1 It jumped out when it saw me.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Shule Elemmire, Phoenix Dissident transmits,
"It jumped out when it saw me."
stop
You press a button to cancel the current autopilot program.

The perfect ring of The Torus spins serenely nearby.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to The Torus (Dock Alpha) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."
Via general sector communication, The Torus transmits, "Greetings, Firestorm!
Welcome to The Torus!"

The ship's computer automatically requests docking clearance.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Dakhal Araegin transmits, "That sounds about
right. When someone actually has guns to shoot with, they'll run off."
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "We detect you to be an AEU ship,
Firestorm. The EAOS welcomes you under the non-aggression pact."
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.

Your ship 'Firestorm' has been automatically moved into a garage.

can reach our performance goals if we try!"

l
[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.
peer out
Not much to see out there.

enter dove
[Starship "William Dove"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, an
early warning space defense device, a glossy sky blue ceramic felo chow bowl,
KitCat the humanoid service robot, a personal hoverpallet, Magellan the
arachnoid security robot, and an insulated red sleeping bag here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
enter
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit
aquarium containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a small white
trash bin, a high tech silver star print holovid, a bulky silver-colored
posterizer, a black plastic tray of spider chow, Purr the humanoid service
robot, and Cheri-Pye the large light violet felo here.
You can go south and out.
l tray
a black plastic tray of spider chow
A small plastic tray containing spider chow pellets. The tray seems just about
full of spider chow.
s
[Starship "William Dove"; Base Block]
You see a soft round ocean blue rug with a design of coral and turquoise
seashells, a blueberry rattan bench with a long white and coral pink flowered
cushion on it, a round white rattan dining table with a glass top, a blueberry
rattan bench with a long white and coral pink flowered cushion on it, a rattan
floor lamp with a coral lotus shade, a blueberry rattan pantry cabinet, a small
dusky pink trash bin, a glossy azure blue ceramic felo chow bowl, and Prissy the
big violet long-haired felo here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.
l tray
an oval white rattan serving tray [inside a leather briefcase]
This oval white serving tray is made of light-weight rattan with a flat wicker
surface.
On it, you see nothing.
s
[Starship "William Dove"; Observation Deck]
You see a large round light purple and dark purple cloth rug, an antique oak
table from Old Earth, a textured plasteel floor lamp with a cream shade (casting
a white-colored glow), a violet leather sectional sofa, a glossy lilac ceramic
felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling coral pink-lit aquarium containing white
and light blue aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic tray of spider
chow, and Shine the big white glowing felo here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.

power

i
 You are wearing a lightweight navy wool suit jacket, a long-sleeved white
cotton dress shirt, a pair of pleated front slim fit navy wool dress pants, and
a pair of black patent leather oxfords. Underneath this, you are wearing a pair
of white cotton briefs and a pair of black silk socks. You are also wearing a
keychain, a backpack, a metallic gold touch einrophone in a black leather phone
holster, a solid silver ring engraved with dolphins, and a gold wrist-mounted
chronometer. You are concealing a metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator,
a flight control scanner, a large expandable telescoping xenology container, a
scorched metal thigh holster, a golden Feng Wo coin purse, a camera bag, a black
engineering tool case, a black flightbag with a red shooting star on the side, a
leather briefcase, and a thick synthleather bandolier with large pockets. Your
head, face, both eyes, neck, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
You are carrying nothing.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Firestorm, you are given undock
clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."

l
[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.
ftl acord
"acord" does not match any known sector.
ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.

A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.
ships
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to AFW Command (Dock One) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."
There are no other ships in the sector.

"Hello, Firestorm. Welcome to Accord space."

keychain, a backpack, a metallic gold touch einrophone in a black leather phone
holster, a solid silver ring engraved with dolphins, and a gold wrist-mounted
chronometer. You are concealing a metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator,
a flight control scanner, a large expandable telescoping xenology container, a
scorched metal thigh holster, a golden Feng Wo coin purse, a camera bag, a black
engineering tool case, a black flightbag with a red shooting star on the side, a
leather briefcase, and a thick synthleather bandolier with large pockets. Your
head, face, both eyes, neck, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
You are carrying nothing.

[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.

The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.

Which sector did you mean?
[1] The Shoulder of Orion (Unclaimed)
[2] The Belt of Orion (Unclaimed)
Enter your selection:
2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
m`xcR{eEM7"dNf52J#m<i9cg7-y"+d;K5vH(y1~P
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to League Salvage Processing Nuclear Autonav Station in thirty seconds
unless aborted or another navigation order is entered."
The computer reports that the two-person bolt thrower "Redemption" has jumped
out of the sector.
The computer reports that the reconnaissance craft "Is This A Dagger Which I See
Before Me?" has jumped out of the sector.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Firestorm.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

green
You lift a small plastic cover and press a green button.
You hear a single beep and glance up to see green lights flick on overhead as
the ship enters normal status.
A low hum you had barely noticed until now slowly fades away as weapons are
powered down.

[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.

communicator? Try typing TRANSMIT LAUGH!

[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.
power

Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.

Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Firestorm, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
ftl chetumal
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Chetumal in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."
Via general sector communication, Chetumal transmits, "Greetings, Firestorm!
Welcome to Chetumal Orbit!"

Enter your destination:
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: Chetumal.
The ship's computer automatically requests landing clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "We detect you to be an AEU ship,
Firestorm. The Fringe welcomes you to the city of Chetumal City under the
non-aggression pact."
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.

This small bowl contains a serving-sized mound of starchy white granules that
resemble rice in appearance, texture, and flavor. Coating the rice is a highly
seasoned light brown sauce flavored with chicken and soy sauce and containing
small white cubes of chicken-flavored meat, chopped green onions, small green
peas, tiny bits of carrots, and flecks of greenish herbs.

[Chetumal Spaceport; Landing Pad]
Carved out of the top of one of the old mountains north of Chetumal City, the
landing pad of this spaceport has an unmatched panoramic view of the
countryside. A low cliff shelters it on the north side, with mail, security, and
repair facilities built into it, and recent construction efforts have expanded
the area and given it a sleek new look. The pad itself consists of a patchwork
of heavy plasteel panels bordered by beams of lighted steel, the panels
variously sized to accommodate any model of starship, no matter how large or
small. A modern but somewhat noisy hydraulic system moves starships between the
landing pad and the garage below. On the south side of the pad is the pilot
lounge with large, tinted windows overlooking the fine Chetumalian landscape to
the south. You can GO into its sleek glass-framed doorway. There is also a
doorway here marked 'Liaison Office,' which you can also GO into. A doorway to
the south leads to the Salvage Reclamation Project Center, and a wide metal
stairway leads down into lower levels of the spaceport.
The three-person clipper "Firestorm" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine, a long row of cinder blocks, and a trash
can here.
You can go north, northeast, south, northwest, and down.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Constantine Stone transmits, "That would be a
sight to behold."

[The Torus; Dock Alpha]
The pale gray walls, floor, and ceiling of this massive EAOS docking bay glow
with a pale white light. Though the bay remains open to space, it somehow also
retains its atmosphere. Outside, you can see the bright glint of a solitary
blue-white star. Signs indicate that the repair and rearm facility, the starship
supply store, and the main concourse are to the north.
The three-person clipper "Firestorm" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go north and down.

posterizer, a black plastic tray of spider chow, Purr the humanoid service
robot, and Shine the big white glowing felo here.

l shine
Shine the big white glowing felo
This strange, six-legged creature is vaguely cat-like, though its head appears
almost vulpine. It is large in size and covered in short, speckled white fur,
possessing a short, sleek tail that slowly flicks back and forth. The felo's
short, thick legs each end in three-toed paws with thin, hooked white claws
visible. A white, square nose sits below a pair of clear blue eyes with vertical
pupils. It puts out a subtle white bioluminescence tinged with light green.

l bowl
a bowl [inside a leather briefcase]

small white cubes of chicken-flavored meat, chopped green onions, small green
peas, tiny bits of carrots, and flecks of greenish herbs.

l
[Starship "Flying Cat"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large
oval white and light blue cloth rug, a walnut coffee table, a white leather
sectional sofa, an overstuffed bright cobalt blue armchair, a wormhole drive
tracer, a glossy pale pink ceramic felo chow bowl, Daizey the humanoid service
robot, a big red feathered felo, and a hefty red feathered felo here.
You can go south and out.

ftl orion
Which sector did you mean?
[1] The Shoulder of Orion (Unclaimed)
[2] The Belt of Orion (Unclaimed)
Enter your selection:
2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
%Zv8F8G}UM1[&+Nb|MxD,waOzRDHrcw8*_gXayn.
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to League Salvage Processing Nuclear Autonav Station in thirty seconds
unless aborted or another navigation order is entered."
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Firestorm.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

proceed to The Torus (Dock Alpha) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another

[The Torus; Dock Alpha]
The pale gray walls, floor, and ceiling of this massive EAOS docking bay glow
with a pale white light. Though the bay remains open to space, it somehow also
retains its atmosphere. Outside, you can see the bright glint of a solitary
blue-white star. Signs indicate that the repair and rearm facility, the starship
supply store, and the main concourse are to the north.
The three-person clipper "Firestorm" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go north and down.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]

l
Your ship 'Firestorm' has been automatically moved into a garage.
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Along this twenty-meter-long section of curving corridor are several doorways,
each set into a shallow alcove with a keypad beside it. In the dim but steady
light, you can see a metal plaque on one of the doorways, reading, 'Damage
Control.' Visitors wandering into this area usually get a stern look from
station personnel passing by, while familiar faces get a nod of recognition. It
is quiet here, footsteps muffled by the thin dark gray carpet.
You can go northeast and south.
ne
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go northeast and southwest.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Smoothly curved and polished metal girders protrude slightly from the finished
walls here, almost decorative in their spacing along the corridor and in the
semicircular wheel-like brace overhead where the girders meet. The light is dim
but steady, provided by tall glowing panels that match the curvature of the
walls. Along the corridor are several doorways set into shallow alcoves, one
identified as 'Trade Licensing and Certification,' though entrance into that
area requires a code unlikely to be known by civilian pilots.
You can go northeast and southwest.
ne
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go east and southwest.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
This long corridor is quiet, footstep muffled by the thin gray carpet covering
the metal floor. The walls curve smoothly into an arch overhead, with polished
steel girders protruding slightly from them and meeting at the apex of the
ceiling with a semicircular wheel-like brace. Between two shadowed doorways here
is a laminated notice of the corridor being closed for maintenance in what might
be the near future.
You can go east and southwest.
ne
You can't go that way.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go east and west.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Here at the north point of the outring, dimly lit corridors extend to the east
and west, curving around the station with geometrically precise construction. On
the north side of the corridor is a security station with mirrored windows set
around the heavily secured doorway, and opposite the security station is a wide
hatch leading south into a spacious, well-lit corridor.
You can go east and west.
go south
[Space Station "Tandem"; Crossway]
You can go south and out.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Crossway]
A few advertisements for shops elsewhere in the station have been affixed to the
walls of this part of the crossway, but the light is dimmer here than elsewhere
and few people venture by. On the north end of the corridor, a wide hatch leads
out into the outring. From here you can see through the hatch to the lights of
one of the station's main security offices, this one located at the north point
of the ring. Toward the south is the station's hub, its light and noise a marked
contrast to this quiet corridor.
You can go south and out.
s
[Space Station "Tandem"; Crossway]
You can go north, east, south, and west.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Crossway]
This corridor is wide but relatively quiet. Traders are rarely seen in this part
of the station, but shoppers come, instead, to browse the shelves of the two
shops located here. On the west side, in an alcove framed by potted ferns bolted
to the floor, is the doorway to a store where hydroponically grown plants are
sold, and on the east side is a container shop, its doorway decorated with rows
of bags firmly glued to a display stand. The station hub is to the south, and
toward the north is the exit of the crossway to the station's outer ring.
You can go north, east, south, and west.
n
[Space Station "Tandem"; Crossway]
You can go south and out.
out
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go east and west.
e
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go southeast and west.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
This curving section of the Outring measures perhaps ten meters wide and twenty
meters long. Arched alcoves along the corridor contain doorways leading to
station facilities. In the dim but steady light provided by the tall glowing
panels recessed into the walls, you can see that the metal plaque beside one
doorway reads: 'Electronics Fabrication.' Beside it are instructions for general
deliveries to the shop.
You can go southeast and west.
se
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go southeast and northwest.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Curved metal girders, polished and reflecting the glow of the lighted panels
along the pale gray walls, brace the ceiling of the long corridor here.
Underfoot is a thin gray carpet, worn in a few places, but dampening the sounds
of footsteps of passersby. Set into an alcove here is a doorway to an office of
the Free Port Authority, though it appears to be locked at the moment.
You can go southeast and northwest.
se
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go south and northwest.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Down this long, curving section of the outring, girders protrude from the walls
at regular intervals, the lengths of polished metal matching the curvature of
the walls and meeting perhaps six meters overhead in a semicircular wheel-like
brace. Between the girders are alcoves containing doorways marked as various
station offices. One of the doorways here has a metal sign bolted to it,
reading, 'Personnel,' and some of the traffic in this area consists of station
workers coming to read the notices mounted to a board beside the doorway.
You can go south and northwest.
s
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
You can go north, east, south, and down.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
This intersection of corridors is about ten meters across and twice as long to
the north and south, the pale gray walls curving smoothly into an arched
ceiling. The walls are smudged in places with oil and grease, and between the
curved girders that support them are several stacks of plastic-covered crates.
On the west side of the area is a wide, open hatch leading into a spacious,
well-lit corridor extending toward the station's central hub, while smaller
hatches to the north and south allow access to the outring around the station.
The sounds of ships landing and launching occasionally come from the corridor
leading east from here. Additionally, built into the wall on the northeast side
of the area, is circular stairway leading downward to a lower level of the
station.
You can go north, east, south, and down.
e
[Space Station "Tandem"; Accessway]
You can go north, east, south, and west.
s
[Space Station "Tandem"; Trading Center]
You can go north.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Trading Center]
A lighted board over the counter here details the ever-changing prices of
commodities bought and sold at the station. Traders come in and out, sometimes
pausing to stare at the board a few moments before quietly approaching the
clerks behind the counter to arrange the transfer of trade items.
You can go north.
n
[Space Station "Tandem"; Accessway]
n
You can go north, east, south, and west.
[Space Station "Tandem"; Mail Center]
You see a trash can here.
You can go south.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Mail Center]
Mail from everywhere in human-occupied space, even the farthest reaches of
Mutuality territory, finds its way here to Tandem's largely automated mail
center. Above the belts that convey packages and mail to and from the back of
the mail room, a menu board relates prices for letters and packages. A
handwritten note beneath encourages pilots to request a load of mail to deliver
themselves.
You see a trash can here.
You can go south.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Accessway]

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]

l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
This corridor is much like a tunnel, though a clean one. The walls are smooth
and pale gray, braced with polished metal girders that meet at the apex of the
arched ceiling in a semicircular wheel-like construct, and the floor is covered
with a dark carpet that has worn a bit thin in places. Inside alcoves along the
corridor are several doorways, among them a damage control station with an
emergency exit map beside it.
You can go north and southwest.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]

l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
The doorways into several offices, all of them unmarked, are set into alcoves
along this curving corridor. Next to one of them is a small black rectangular
panel that appears to be inoperative at the moment. Though the air is cool, warm
air constantly circulates upward from vents near the floor, alleviating the deep
cold of space just beyond the confines of the station.
You can go northeast and southwest.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Every doorway set into the alcoves along this section of corridor has a plaque
on it, reading: 'Private.' People occasionally come along, but no one seems to
ever enter or come out of these doorways.

l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
This long, curving corridor is dimly lit, but through a hatch on the north side,
a bright spacious corridor extends toward the center of the station. Beside the
hatch is a faded sign warning of the dangers of sudden decompression. Opposite
the hatch, along the south side of the corridor, is a security office with
mirrored windows set around its heavily secured doorway.
You can go east and west.

four-pointed star superimposed over an open circle.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
Lighted panels recessed into the walls along this long, curving corridor provide
a dim but steady illumination, the light glimmering off polished metal girders
protruding from the walls and following their curvature upward to the smoothly
arched ceiling where they meet in a semicircular wheel-like brace. Among the
doors inset into shallow alcoves here is the Office of Trade Rates Coordination
and Arbitration.

alcoves, among them the Trade and Tax Regulation Office. It is not unusual to
see weary and sometimes exasperated traders lined up in the hallway near the
office, awaiting their turn inside.

l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Throughway]
Polished steel girders brace the walls here, meeting overhead in the arch of the
ceiling where a red and black Mutuality banner hangs, the fabric stirring
slightly in the warm air wafting up from the ventilation system beneath the
floor. Along this section of corridor, a wide doorway opens south to Tandem's
taxi station, though some sort of construction is taking place there and, as a
result, the facility is not open for business. Another open entrance leads north
into a general clothing store advertised by a rack of attractive clothing
standing just outside the recessed doorway.
You can go north, east, and west.
w
[Space Station "Tandem"; Throughway]
You can go east and west.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Throughway]
The center of the floor here has been left uncarpeted, allowing air to circulate
upward from the ventilation system that runs beneath the floor, the warm air
rippling the Mutuality banner hanging from the polished girders that meet at the
apex of the arched ceiling overhead. Traders, visitors, and station residents
move easily through the corridor, though a long line often forms at the kiosk of
a taco vendor here, the aroma of freshly cooked food too tempting to resist.
Just to the west is the station's hub, noisy and brightly lit.
You can go east and west.
w
[Space Station "Tandem"; Hub]
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest,
up, and down.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Hub]
Perhaps twenty meters in diameter, the hub of the station is a bustling,
brightly lit place. Popular businesses are accorded space here, including a
crowded restaurant, a rather seedy bar, and a gaudy souvenir shop. In addition
to the shoppers milling about, traders and travelers gather in small groups
around a wide circular stairway in the middle of the hub. Apart from them are
station residents, known by their relaxed manner and dress. Around the perimeter
of the hub are wide corridors leading north, south, east, and west to other
parts of the station.
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest,
up, and down.
peer se
You peer southeast...
[Space Station "Tandem"; Spacers]
Tinny popular music plays in the background of this crowded little restaurant.
The light is bright, and the floor looks clean. Though people mill about
somewhat chaotically, crowding around the long counter near the back to place
their orders and jostling each other as they find seating on the benches pulled
up to the two long black plastic tables in the center of the room, the air here
seems oxygen-rich, probably due to the long black planters along the walls, each
one overflowing with green ferns and leafy plants.
You see a trash can here.
You can go northwest.
peer ne
You peer northeast...
[Space Station "Tandem"; Souvenirs]
Crammed onto every available inch of shelf space here are inexpensive souvenirs,
some of them useful, most not. Banners and flags hang from the ceiling, and at
the end of each aisle is a bin of stuffed toys. A small clothing section adds to
the capitalist ambiance, as souvenir t-shirts and underwear are snatched up
nearly as soon as they are restocked.
You see a trash can here.
You can go southwest.
peer nw
You peer northwest...
[Space Station "Tandem"; Shipsuits]
Hanging from clothing racks arranged into aisles down the middle of this popular
shop are numerous styles of shipsuits, all constructed of the cheap but durable
synthetic fabrics so common among spacers. Though Mutuality colors predominate,
a good selection of other colors are also on display.
You see a trash can here.
You can go southeast.
peer sw
You peer southwest...
[Space Station "Tandem"; Bright's Bar]
Smelling of roasted peanuts and spilled beer, with a long bar near the back
surrounded by padded bar stools, and dented metal tables placed here and there
across the center of the room, this dimly lit establishment resembles crowded,
shabby bars anywhere. It is distinguished, however, by the rare collection of
neon shapes on the walls that cast oddly colored lights on the faces of its
clientele, and the assortment of spacer-beloved beverages on the menu. You see a
very large black jersey labeled 'JUPITER CRASH' hanging on a wall.
You see a battered holovid, a trash can, and a dark red and black payshoes
interface here.
You can go northeast.

the only note of real interest in this otherwise simply furnished area. In the

l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Throughway]
Two shops occupy space along this section of corridor. On the north side, a shop
called Fluidity advertises water and water-related wares with big balloon-like
bubbles hanging around the sign over the doorway, and on the south side is a
fabulously popular gelatin store decorated with a rainbow-hued sign, reading,
"Gelatin Supply! All Colors! Get them NOW!.' It's not unusual to see spacers
wheeling away whole cases of the stuff from there. Down toward the east is the
brightly lit central hub of the station.
You can go north, east, south, and west.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Grand Conference Room]

l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Grand Conference Room]
Numerous long, narrow windows of transparisteel framed in black give this
circular conference room a view that can be found nowhere else on the station.
Though you can see little but distant stars through the windows, starships can
occasionally be observed moving through nearby space to dock at the station. In
the center of the room, decorated in black, red, and gunmetal gray, is a large
round table of ebony steel with the symbol of the Tandem Pact engraved in the
middle. Comfortably padded black chairs surround the large table, and overhead
is a round ring of lights that shed a soft illumination over the room.
You can go down.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Lower Hub]
Lit by regularly spaced panels recessed into the walls, this area is circular,
with a winding staircase in the center of it leading up to a higher level of the
station, where it is always brighter and noisier than here. The same staircase
has a downward extension, but it is blocked by a metal grate with a sign on it.
To the east and west are long corridors, and to the north is a quiet area, its
arched entrance framed with a slender, smoothly curved water panel, the small
bubbles inside continually generated and rising upward to the apex of the arch.
You can go north, east, west, and up.

ftl new
1
The starship is already moving.
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Firestorm!
Welcome to home space!"

wait.

A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: New Earth.
The ship's computer automatically requests landing clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Hello, Firestorm. We read your AEU
transponder. You are cleared to land at the city of New Phoenix."

[New Earth; ITPN Station; Main Circuit]
Huge walls of windows line this semicircular station room. Travelers mill about,
watching the large display boards suspended from the high ceiling, and new
arrivals stream out toward the reception area. Pods arrive and leave through a
broad circular opening in the ceiling, landing with superb precision on a
central platform. Broad steps lead up to the passenger loading area, where a
white-gloved attendant directs traffic. To the west, you can see the nearly
identical AEU Circuit station through a tall archway.
You can go west and northwest.
Your ship 'Firestorm' has been automatically moved into a garage.
A display indicates that ITPN Main Circuit Pod One is due to arrive within
seconds.
ITPN Main Circuit Pod One suddenly hurtles into the area and is slowed abruptly
by an electromagnetic field. A display begins counting down the 30 seconds until
it departs for its next stop, Chetumal.

[ITPN Main Circuit Pod One]
This transport pod is spheroid, with a broad band of transparent plasteel around
its center. Several rows of seats line the inner edge, and each seat is equipped
with a bit of rubberized webbing to secure its passenger. Small displays next to
each seat provide the ROUTE for this pod, with the current destination always at
the top of the list. A chromed ring of tubular plasteel is mounted to the
ceiling, with a number of hand grips dangling from it for those who choose to
remain standing. Soft carpeting in a subtle blue and black ripple pattern covers
the floor.
You can go out.
You feel sudden acceleration as the pod begins travelling to the next stop.
route
Route for ITPN Main Circuit Pod One
===================================
1. Chetumal
2. The Torus
3. Residential Structure
4. Tandem Station
5. Old Earth
6. New Earth
The pod vibrates violently as it approaches and enters a wormhole.

[Space Station "Tandem"; ITPN Station; Main Circuit]

[Space Station "Tandem"; ITPN Station; Main Circuit]
This square room of pale gray walls and polished metal girders is centered
around a platform where transport pods occasionally land and then take off
through a broad hole in the ceiling. A thick metal railing surrounds the
platform, which is accessed by a set of metal stairs attended by a white-gloved
ITPN agent. Large portholes in the bulkhead provide lonely views of deep space.
Informational displays hang on the four walls, providing estimated times of
arrival and departure. A stairway leads down to the corridor below.
You see ITPN Main Circuit Pod One here.
You can go down.
peer d
You peer down...
[Space Station "Tandem"; Accessway]
In this long corridor, polished metal girders matching the curvature of the pale
gray walls arc overhead, except on the far wall where a set of stairs leading up
to the ITPN Station has been built along the outer bulkhead. Tall lighted panels
are recessed into the walls, and the metal mesh of the floor allows warm air to
circulate upward from the ventilation system beneath. Beyond a wide hatch to the
north, technicians and mechanics can be seen rushing around in the station's
Repair and Rearm facility, while the starship supply store to the south seems
relatively quiet with several large unopened crates stacked beside the hatch
there. To the west is another wide hatch leading to a cavernous space that can
only be one of the station's docking bays.
You can go north, east, south, west, and up.
The countdown until departure reaches 15 seconds.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]

You can't go that way.
l
[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
About ten meters across and twice as long to the north and south, this section
of smoothly finished gray corridor curves slightly as part of the outer ring of
the station, commonly called the Outring. Polished metal girders protrude from
the walls, which arch gradually to meet overhead. Though the light here is never
bright, the tall glowing panels recessed into the walls provide a steady
illumination. On the east side of this area is a wide, open hatch leading into a
spacious corridor extending toward the center of the station. Smaller hatches
follow the outring around the station to the north and south, and the sounds of
ships landing and launching often comes from the corridor leading west from
here. In one corner of the intersection, a narrow circular set of stairs leads
down to a lower level.
You can go north, south, west, and down.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Outring]
This intersection of corridors is about ten meters across and twice as long to
the north and south, the pale gray walls curving smoothly into an arched
ceiling. The walls are smudged in places with oil and grease, and between the
curved girders that support them are several stacks of plastic-covered crates.
On the west side of the area is a wide, open hatch leading into a spacious,
well-lit corridor extending toward the station's central hub, while smaller
hatches to the north and south allow access to the outring around the station.
The sounds of ships landing and launching occasionally come from the corridor
leading east from here. Additionally, built into the wall on the northeast side
of the area, is circular stairway leading downward to a lower level of the
station.
You can go north, east, south, and down.

[Space Station "Tandem"; Repair & Rearm]
The activity in this large facility borders on chaos as technicians in
oil-stained orange jumpsuits rush in and out, repairing, rearming, and
maintaining the starships docked at the station. On shelves bolted to the walls,
numerous small tortured ship parts are on display as a caution to those who
can't or won't maintain their ships. Over the counter near the back is a lighted
menuboard detailing the prices for station services.
You can go south.
